name: Nanking Massacre (Rape of Nanking)
description: The Japanese Imperial Army's rampage through the Chinese capital after its capture in December 1937. Over six weeks, soldiers killed an estimated 200,000-300,000 civilians and prisoners of war. Systematic rape affected up to 80,000 women. Japan's denial continues to strain relations with China.

mortality.note: Occurred over approximately 6 weeks. Estimates vary widely - China claims 300,000+, some Japanese historians dispute figures.

rationales.systematic_intensity: Six weeks of uncontrolled violence. Mass rape, murder, arson. Command breakdown.
rationales.profit: Looting occurred but not primary driver. War atrocity not economic system.
rationales.ideology: Japanese militarism and racism toward Chinese, but massacre was chaotic not planned.
rationales.complicity: Japanese military command failed to stop violence. International witnesses documented. Japan disputes numbers.

analysis.pattern_note: Lower systematic intensity despite massive death toll - this was chaotic military violence rather than bureaucratic genocide. Shows that industrial organization isn't required for mass death. Still denied/minimized in Japan, creating ongoing diplomatic tensions with China.
analysis.root_causes: Japanese militarism, racism toward Chinese, lack of command accountability

sources.title: The Nanjing Massacre in History and Historiography
sources.author: Joshua Fogel
